def: {bc} to bend or move from a straight position
{bc} to cause (something) to bend or move from a straight position
{bc} to rest {it}on{/it} or {it}against{/it} something or someone for support

dt: {bc}to bend or move from a straight position

dt.t: The tree {it}leans{/it} to one side.
He {it}leaned{/it} back in his chair.
They {it}leaned{/it} over the table to smell the flowers.

dt: {bc}to cause (something) to bend or move from a straight position

dt.t: They {it}leaned{/it} their heads back.
He {it}leaned{/it} his chair back.

dt: {bc}to rest {it}on{/it} or {it}against{/it} something or someone for support

dt.t: You can {it}lean on{/it} me if you get tired.
She stood {it}leaning on{/it} her right leg.
The ladder was {it}leaning against{/it} the house.
He {it}leaned{/it} the ladder {it}against{/it} the house.
The boy {it}leaned{/it} his head {it}on{/it} his mother's shoulder.

dt: used to describe what someone wants to do, tends to do, or is likely to do

dt.t: She hasn't made a decision yet, and I don't know which way she's {it}leaning{/it}.
She's {it}leaning toward{/it} a career in medicine. [=she is probably going to choose a career in medicine]
The mayor is {it}leaning toward{/it} closing down the school.

dt: used to say that someone supports one group or set of beliefs more than another

dt.t: an independent presidential candidate who {it}leans toward{/it} the Democrats and their views

dt: used to say that something is more like one thing than another

dt.t: Her new album {it}leans{/it} more {it}toward{/it} rock than country.

dt: {bc}to depend on (someone or something) for support

dt.t: He {it}leaned on{/it} his family during the crisis.
She was someone you could {it}lean on{/it}.

dt: {bc}to force or try to force (someone) to do something especially by making threats {bc}to put pressure on (someone)

dt.t: They were {it}leaning on{/it} the governor to pass the law.

shortdef: to bend or move from a straight position
to cause (something) to bend or move from a straight position
to rest on or against something or someone for support

def: {bc} not having much fat on the body {bc} physically thin, strong, and healthy
{bc} not having or producing much money, food, etc.

dt: {bc}not having much fat on the body {bc}physically thin, strong, and healthy

dt.t: She has a {it}lean{/it}, athletic body.
a {it}lean{/it} racehorse
{it}lean{/it} meat
({it}US{/it}) {it}lean{/it} ground beef

dt: {bc}not having or producing much money, food, etc.

dt.t: Those were {it}lean{/it} years for the company. [=the company did not make much money in those years]
a {it}lean{/it} budget/profit/harvest

dt: {bc}not using a lot of something (such as words or money)

dt.t: He had a {it}lean{/it} style of writing. [=his writing style did not use too many words]
She ran a {it}lean{/it} and efficient company.
We wanted our business to be {phrase}lean and mean{/phrase}.

pt: {sc}lean{/sc}, {sc}thin{/sc}, and {sc}skinny{/sc} mean not having much fat on the body. {sc}lean{/sc} suggests a lack of unnecessary fat and may also suggest the muscular body of an athlete.

pt.t: the strong {it}lean{/it} legs of a runner

pt: {sc}thin{/sc} can describe a person whose lack of fat is unhealthy, but it also often describes a person who is considered attractive.

pt.t: The room was full of beautiful {it}thin{/it} women.

pt: {sc}skinny{/sc} describes a person who has an extremely thin appearance and who may not be healthy or eat enough food.

shortdef: not having much fat on the body : physically thin, strong, and healthy
not having or producing much money, food, etc.

def: {bc} a small and usually roughly made building that is built on the side of a larger building

dt: {bc}a small and usually roughly made building that is built on the side of a larger building

shortdef: a small and usually roughly made building that is built on the side of a larger building

def: {bc} in, toward, or at the back or rear
{bc} to, toward, or in the place where someone or something was previously
{bc} in or into the past {bc} backward in time {it}also{/it}

dt: {bc}in, toward, or at the back or rear

dt.t: The soldiers moved {it}back{/it} from the front lines.
The police asked the crowd to move/step {it}back{/it} from the scene of the accident.
He left his friends two miles {it}back{/it}.
She turned around and looked {it}back{/it} toward him.
a chapter beginning several pages {it}back{/it}

dt: {bc}to, toward, or in the place where someone or something was previously

dt.t: He left his home and never went {it}back{/it}.
I had to go {it}back{/it} (to the office) for some papers I had left behind.
It's time to go {it}back{/it} home.
She took the book off the shelf and forgot to put it {it}back{/it}.
She left earlier but she should {phrase}be back{/phrase} [={it}return{/it}] soon.

dt: {bc}in or into the past {bc}backward in time

dt.t: In the opening chapter the author looks {it}back{/it} on his youth.
an event {it}back{/it} in the last century
It happened several years {it}back{/it}.
I met him in the city two days {it}back{/it}.

dt: {bc}to or toward a former state or condition

dt.t: He has decided to go {it}back{/it} to private life. [=to return to private life]
Good farming practices were needed to bring the fields {it}back{/it} (to good condition). [=to restore the fields]
I gave the book to him and he gave it {it}back{/it} (to me).
He refused to give {it}back{/it} the borrowed money.
He hit his brother and his brother hit him right {it}back{/it}.
talk {it}back{/it}
She refused to take {it}back{/it} her accusations.

dt: used to describe someone or something that is being held or kept from moving forward or happening

dt.t: He would have jumped if his friends had not held him {it}back{/it}.
He vowed that he wouldn't allow poverty to hold/keep him {it}back{/it}. [=to keep him from succeeding]
She struggled to hold {it}back{/it} a laugh. [=to keep from laughing]
Landslides set the construction job {it}back{/it} many days. [=caused the construction job to be delayed many days]

dt: used to describe something that is being kept instead of being given or revealed

dt.t: They held {it}back{/it} part of the money.
keep {it}back{/it} the truth
The banks slant evenly {it}back{/it} from the highway.
The doctor told her to {phrase}lie back{/phrase} on the couch. [=to lie down on the couch]
When I get home from work I like to just {phrase}sit/lean back{/phrase} on the couch and relax.
There's an old tractor out {it}back of{/it} [={it}in back of{/it}] the barn.

shortdef: in, toward, or at the back or rear
to, toward, or in the place where someone or something was previously
in or into the past : backward in time; also : ago

def: {bc} toward the back {bc} to or toward what is behind
{bc} opposite to the usual way {bc} in reverse

dt: {bc}toward the back {bc}to or toward what is behind

dt.t: a sudden movement {it}backward{/it}, not forward
I heard a noise behind me and glanced {it}backward{/it}.
He pushed the throttle {it}backward{/it}.
She took a small step {it}backward{/it}.
Can you skate {it}backward{/it}?
Count {it}backward{/it} from 10.
a journey {it}backward{/it} in time
The narrative moves {it}backward{/it} and forward in time.

dt: {bc}to or toward a less advanced state or condition {bc}toward a worse state

dt.t: His new job, which paid less and had fewer responsibilities, felt like a step {it}backward{/it}.

dt: {bc}to make a great effort to help someone or to reach agreement with someone

dt.t: The salesman said he would {it}bend over backward{/it} to make the deal.
I've {it}leaned over backward{/it} to please you—and you haven't even said thank you!

shortdef: toward the back : to or toward what is behind
opposite to the usual way : in reverse

def: {bc} not kind to people {bc} cruel or harsh
{it}chiefly British{/it} {bc} not liking to spend money

dt.t: My boss is a {it}mean{/it} and nasty old man who treats everyone badly.
the {it}mean{/it} stepmother in the fairy tale
Why are you being so {it}mean{/it} to me? [=why are you treating me so harshly?]
It was {it}mean{/it} of them not to invite her to the party.
Someone played a {it}mean{/it} trick on her.
He has a {it}mean{/it} streak.
a {it}mean{/it} dog
He's a {it}mean{/it} man who never gives presents to anyone.
He's very {it}mean{/it} with his money.
{it}mean{/it} city streets
living in {it}mean{/it} circumstances
He plays a {it}mean{/it} trumpet. = He's a {it}mean{/it} trumpet player. [=he plays the trumpet very well]
an athlete who describes himself as a {phrase}lean, mean{/phrase} scoring machine
We wanted our business to be {phrase}lean and mean{/phrase}. [=to be efficient and successful]

dt: used to say that something is good or impressive

dt.t: a tennis player of {it}no mean{/it} ability [=a very good tennis player]
Getting the project done on time will be {phrase}no mean feat{/phrase}. [=will be a difficult and impressive accomplishment]

shortdef: not kind to people : cruel or harsh
not liking to spend money : stingy cheap
